SINGAPORE SELETAR CHINESE OLD BOYS' ASSOCIATION
(Registration)


    1. Mr Lim Ching Siong asked the Chief Secretary what were the reasons for the refusal to register the Singapore Seletar Chinese Old Boys' Association.

SINGAPORE BUS WORKERS' UNION
(Strike-Breaking)


    2. Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim asked the Minister for Communications and Works what action he has taken on the complaint by the Singapore Bus Workers' Union regarding a certain Bus Company employing excess workers for the purpose of strike-breaking.

    Mr Francis Thomas: I have informed the Singapore Bus Workers' Union that bus workers are licensed by the Registrar of Vehicles - a City Council employee.

    Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim: Will the Minister consider asking the City Council to stop providing badges for the new recruitment because, to my knowledge, the recruitment of new hands is entirely for strike-breaking?

    Mr Speaker: It is entirely a new question.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: May I ask a supplementary question, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, Mr Lee Kuan Yew.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Will the Minister for Transport inform us what he considers is a just solution to this dispute?

    Mr Francis Thomas: That is asking for an opinion.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Has he made up his mind on what he proposes to do about this dispute?

Column: 1222



    Mr Francis Thomas: If the hon. leader of the People's Action Party cannot inform himself of my title, he will continue to make mistakes as to my functions. I am not the Minister for Transport. He might have learnt that if he had studied his Estimates. If he had studied anything, he might have learnt that I am not the Minister for Transport, that I have no powers to deal with transport-strikes, disputes, issue of licences. They are all matters which are handled by other authorities.

GOVERNMENT POLICY IN LABOUR NEGOTIATIONS


    3. Mr Lim Ching Siong asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether he will explain what policy he adopts towards employers of labour who refuse to negotiate with Unions which represent the majority of their employees and give recognition only to a Union representing a minority.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: The recognition of trade unions by employers is a matter for employers themselves. I have no powers to compel an employer to negotiate with any union, whether the union can substantiate a claim to represent a majority of employees or not, to the exclusion of other unions. It is a policy of my Ministry, however, to encourage employers to negotiate with trade unions which clearly represent effectively a majority of their employees, or even clearly defined sections of their employees. The ultimate decision rests with the employer who may be faced with all the damaging results of inter-trade-union warfare if he comes to a wrong decision. I would mention, for the information of this Assembly, that the question of recasting the law affecting industrial relations is under consideration.

UNITED ENGINEERS STRIKE
(Court of Inquiry)


    4. Mr Lim Ching Siong asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether he will reconsider his decision not to appoint a Court of Inquiry to investigate the causes of the dispute between the United Engineers Ltd. and its striking employees; and whether he will order such

Column: 1223

an immediate Inquiry, and cause the findings of this Inquiry to be published for public information.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: In order to answer this question, Sir, I have reconsidered my decision not to appoint a Court of Inquiry to investigate the causes of the dispute between the United Engineers Ltd. and its striking employees. I consider that the facts of the dispute are generally sufficiently well-known not to require the appointment of a Court of Inquiry to establish them. I also consider that the dispute does not involve any matters of vital interest to Singapore, and that the circumstances do not merit the setting up of a Court of Inquiry.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Minister for Labour consider that a peaceful strike is a matter which does not affect the vital interests of Singapore?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: As I have said, Sir, the circumstances that led to this strike are well-known to the public of Singapore, and those circumstances do not merit the setting up of a Court of Inquiry.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Minister for Labour propose to wait until there is a riot before he institutes a Court of Inquiry?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, there is no existing issue of a vital character that affects the interests of the public.

TRADE DISPUTES ORDINANCE
(Picketing)


    5. Mr Lim Ching Siong asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether he is aware that from the workers' point of view the provisions relating to picketing in the local Trade Disputes Ordinance are susceptible of improvement; and whether he will consider introducing legislation to bring the provisions of the local Trade Disputes Ordinance into line with the Trade Disputes Act in force in the United Kingdom.

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: I would explain that the Trade Disputes Ordinance legalises strikes and other actions by trade

Column: 1224

unions and striking employees which, because they do damage to an employer's trade or business, might otherwise be criminal offences.

    Another aspect of this Ordinance is that it codifies the powers of picketing. In this connection, I note that certain pseudo trade unionists are repeatedly blaming the Police for interfering with what they call peaceful picketing. I should like to take this opportunity to stress that in their interpretation of the Trade Disputes Ordinance, which is a perfectly clear law, the Police are not depriving strikers of their lawful right to carry on picketing in a peaceful manner, and that they are solely concerned with the enforcement of the law on obstruction, intimidation, or behaviour calculated to lead to a breach of the peace. The Government will carefully consider not only any constructive suggestions for improvement of the Ordinance from the point of view of the workers, but will also be obliged to take into consideration the views of employers and also considerations of public safety.

    In regard to the second part of the question, I can assure the Member for Bukit Timah that the question of amending the Trade Disputes Ordinance has been occupying my mind for some time. But I must say that I am only prepared to introduce amending legislation if I consider the interests of Singapore require it, and not merely because the legislation has been enacted elsewhere.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does the Minister for Labour realise that the legislation which is now in force in this Colony was enacted here because it was enacted elsewhere, copied therefrom?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, two wrongs do not make one right!

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Will the Minister for Labour tell us what he meant by a pseudo trade unionist?

    Mr Lim Yew Hock: Please look up the dictionary!

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: It does not answer the question.

Column: 1225

SECURITY OF TENURE FOR FARMERS


    6. Mr Lim Ching Siong asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he will consider introducing legislation to obtain security of tenure for farmers who at present occupy Crown Land under temporary Occupation Licences, in order to put such land into more productive use.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Authority to issue leases for Crown land exists under the Crown Lands Ordinance and the rules made thereunder. The Master Plan for Singapore, which will be published on the 3rd of January next, will indicate what areas of the island are to be reserved for agriculture, and it is the intention to give security of tenure to all farmers occupying Crown land in these areas by issuing to them leases on such terms relating to development and proper cultivation as may be considered necessary.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I move that that motion be taken in two parts? The Chief Minister is suggesting that we give a vote on the wishes of the Government that, if the business is not completed, we will go on tomorrow, but that if it is, then the Chief Minister would not like to proceed to business, of which notice has already been given, for tomorrow.

    I would ask that the motion by the Chief Minister be put in two parts so that those Members of this House, who feel that in any case the Assembly should go on till tomorrow, could vote on that motion.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, may I speak on that?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, certainly.

    The Chief Minister: It is not the intention on the part of the Government to try to avoid any business that was laid down. The business for this sitting, Sir, has been adumbrated a long time ago. Hon. Members have had opportunities to place such motions and questions as they wished for Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. They wished to place it for Friday and took the risk that there is no business on Thursday. Surely they take their own risk, but I would like to add this: that if the leaders of the Parties on the Opposition Benches feel generally that they would, in spite of the fact that there is little business to be done tomorrow, nevertheless like to sit tomorrow to consider the little business that is set down for tomorrow, Government wishes to take no exception to that procedure. I would rather that there should be agreement on this than that we should take a vote on the subject. If the leaders of the Opposition Parties would indicate their wishes, I am quite prepared to fall in with them.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, I can speak on behalf of the Opposition Members on this side of the House that they are of the opinion that, in any event, the business which is down for tomorrow should be proceeded with.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Chairman, Sir, when speaking in this House on the Second Reading, I made three main points when referring to education. Firstly, that the Government should find ways and means of reducing the cost of primary school buildings so that the money available can be made to stretch further. Secondly, that the absence of any new provision for the building of secondary schools was a glaring omission; and thirdly, that there was no indication in the Government's programme that there was to be any early reorientation in educational policy.

    As regards the first point, I do not think that there is any need to repeat myself or elaborate, except to make quite clear that we are against the cutting down of the primary school building programme as far as the number of schools is concerned. What we feel convinced about is that there can be a considerable reduction in building costs, but I cannot believe that plans are too far ahead, as far as the 1956 programme is concerned, to prevent the necessary action being taken. Let me repeat once more, that this problem should be the special concern of an Estimates Committee of this House, and for some reason or another, which needs explaining, the Government appears to have been extremely reluctant to set up this Committee.

    The Chief Minister: That is not true.

    Mr John Ede: As far as secondary education is concerned, Sir, I am still not convinced that all is well. A fortnight ago the Minister stated categorically that six schools would be completed in 1956. On Monday last he was candid enough to say that only two would be completed, if I understood him, and later the Financial Secretary corrected him and made it four. Whatever the meaning of these apparent contradictions, we are faced already this year with about 2,000 students having to be failed in an examination for entry to secondary schools, not because of lack of skill, but because there is no accommodation for them. It is true, of course,

Column: 1230

that some of these rejected students will find their way into the new technical schools, the junior technical school, into aided schools, or Chinese schools. Some, of course, are not of a high enough intellectual standard to benefit from secondary education and will leave school to join family businesses and so on. But the balance of students remaining who need secondary education from January and will not get it is still formidable. I do not think that the Minister for Education will accuse me of exaggerating if I say that this balance would be enough to fill another two secondary schools, possibly three, but certainly not less than two. If the secondary school programme for 1955 had been completed, this shortage would not have arisen.

    Worse still, the shortage will increase next year with increasing numbers of students completing the primary stage, and once you start cutting down on the policy of one new secondary school for every four primary schools built, you are, in fact, following a policy of putting young students of 14 and 15 on to the streets. Quite apart from the dangers of this course, we are at a loss to understand the Government policy. A lack of secondary schools means a reduction in the number of students who can be trained as teachers to man more schools in the future; a reduction in those being sent for higher education in the University of Malaya and abroad, and hence a reduction of highly qualified local men to enter the civil service or commerce and industry. Malayanisation has no meaning as a policy if it is to be stifled at the outset by lack of adequate higher education facilities for the younger generation. In our view, therefore, the Minister's educational policy is not in the best interests of the country and needs radical changes. It is indeed a retrograde policy which could bring us into serious trouble in a few years, and a direct reversal of Progressive Party policy which fought for years with the previous official Government to get secondary education given its proper place.

    Before I leave secondary education, Sir, I would suggest to the Minister that he considers more seriously what he can do

Column: 1231

for the 2,000 students who will fail to get entry to secondary schools next year. He has stated that bright over-aged students will be given a chance to skip a year of secondary education and qualify for Std. VII, but he has given no solution for the average-aged students who are still virtually unemployable at the completion of the primary education stage, partly because of age and partly because of an insufficiently high educational attainment. Something must be done to make these young people employable, so that they can make their own way in life. They must not be left to drift into undesirable company and become loafers or worse. It has been suggested that just as the intake of primary schools has been doubled by having morning and afternoon schools, the same should be done in respect of secondary schools, but I believe there are practical difficulties in the way of this apparently simple solution, because secondary schools spill over into the afternoons, particularly science periods; in other words, there is no clear cessation of work at one p.m. But not all class-rooms are full in the afternoons, and therefore I hand the Minister this suggestion. Start a two- or three-year intensive course in a limited number of subjects and make them available to these otherwise unwanted students; in other words, bridge the gap between unemployability and employability and give them a chance in life, even if it is only in junior posts, but do not abandon them. Parents would rather have their children busy with this limited type of training than running wild. I hope that earnest consideration be given to setting up a scheme of this kind in motion early in the new year.

    My third charge against the Government was that no consideration had been given to a reorientation of the educational policy of this country. No doubt, my hon. Friend will say that he is waiting for the completion of the now long overdue Report of the All-Party Education Committee, but I would remind him that the terms of reference limited that Committee to consideration of the problems of Chinese education and Chinese schools. Although the suggestion has been made

Column: 1232

that the Government should build a Chinese secondary school, a Malay secondary school, or a Tamil secondary school on the basis of its policy of equal treatment in education for all, and although the Minister has indicated that a Chinese secondary school, I think it was, is to be built next year, it is by no means clear to me that the sum required has been budgeted for unless it is one of the two which he now says will be completed in 1956.

    Yet it is quite clear that speed in this matter is essential, and Government should have hastened the completion of the All-Party Committee's Report so that it could have been debated in this House this year instead of in February next year, or even later, or make a start with its policy where it cannot conflict with anything the Report may reveal. Just to set aside $20 millions for grants-in-aid to vernacular schools is not a policy, and we on this side of the House are not happy in approving a lump sum amounting to ten per cent of the country's revenue without Government coming to us for sanction as to how this amount should be spent. I am not against it being spent on education, or wholly on vernacular education. That is understood and agreed. But we may find that the whole of the money should not be spent on full grants-in-aid to individual schools, but that the promotion of sound vernacular education can best be promoted if part of it is spent in other ways. It may be best, for example, to allocate some of it to a special branch of the Teachers Training College for the training of teachers for Chinese, Malay and Indian schools. Some of it may be required for more suitable textbooks and so on. I hope that the Minister will give an assurance that this huge grant will be put to the best possible use for what I have called the reorientation of our educational policy.

    Speaking broadly, and more broadly than the All-Party Committee is empowered by its terms of reference to speak, I would suggest that education has three main purposes: firstly, to equip boys or girls to earn their living; secondly, to equip them to play their part as

Column: 1233

citizens of a democracy; and thirdly, to enable them to develop all the powers and faculties latent in their nature so as to enjoy life in all its fullness. These purposes are complementary to each other and a proper education will seek to secure all three, and all of them within the framework of a Malayan nationalism. It follows, therefore, that all the main languages and cultures which should make up that composite thing which can be called Malayan nationalism must be regarded as complementary to each other and not as existing separately in water-tight compartments.

    I believe that a way will have to be found, and found at once, to achieve the following three objectives. Firstly, the total eradication of the charge, erroneous but real, that there is a plot to exterminate the Malay and Chinese and Indian cultures. Secondly, the total eradication of the charge, for which there is some substance, that our young people in English schools are being brought up as imitation Westerners with no real cultural roots of their own. And, thirdly, the free and equal choice of parents to decide whether their children are to have a predominantly Chinese, or Malay, or Indian, or English education, and yet always within a Malayan framework. I was a teacher of English in an Indian college founded on English models for over ten years and perhaps I can claim to know something of the problems.

    If we are to live together in this small country in peace and goodwill, we have to found a Malayan nationalism which transcends individual nationalism. The more we understand each other's languages, the more we shall understand each other's minds and the less shall we be set within the rigid confines of our own particular community. While it is true that we see best through the eyes of our own community, or race, or nationalism, it is also true that we only see imperfectly. By learning each other's languages and about each other's cultures, we find that we can see more than we could before, because we see, to some extent, through each other's eyes also. In this way we can rise to the idea of a common synthesis, something which we can all see

Column: 1234

through learning many-sidedness; and we shall then see that a Malayan culture can transcend the Chinese, or Malay, or Indian, or European cultures without destroying or belittling any of them; and we shall then know that it is not merely possible but indeed the duty to begin by being a good Malay, or a good Chinese, or a good Indian or a good European, and then to make one further step without losing that quality - and become a good Malayan. I do not believe that you can talk about an educational policy in any other way. I do not believe that you can gain a happy and prosperous future for Singapore and Malaya in any other way, and it is our hope that the Government will take an early step forward in the promulgation of such a policy.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, may I congratulate the substantive leader of the Progressive Party for putting forward a point of view which we, on this side of this side of the House, have been advocating for so long? It is a decided step forward when a right-wing Party understands that militant agitation for equality of treatment in education is not Communist propaganda. We fully endorse what has been said about the necessity of harmonising the various cultural and linguistic groups in the country. We endorse the hope that the Government will find it possible in the very near future to formulate a definite policy within either their four-year term of office, or their two-year term of office, to give a beginning to this re-orientated education policy.

    Mr Chairman, Sir, I wish to add to what the Member for Tanglin has said on primary and secondary education by commenting on University education. There is a vote, out of this 46 odd million dollars, of $2.38 millions, contribution to the University of Malaya. It is our earnest hope that the University of Malaya would not continue in its role of being an institution for purely English higher education. Either that role must be changed, or, in pursuance of this policy of equality of treatment for all languages and all cultural groups, other universities must be founded to

Column: 1235

meet the demands of the other linguistic and cultural groups. So far, the University of Malaya has not captured the imagination of the Chinese-speaking, Indian-speaking, or Malay-speaking groups. Indeed, even amongst the English-speaking group it has not succeeded in bringing home the fact that here is an institution which, if a Malayan civilisation is to flourish in Malaya, must foster the leaders, not necessarily the economic leaders, but the cultural and intellectual leaders of the Malaya of tomorrow. It is important that in this seat of learning the highest traditions of academic freedom should be observed.

    Mr Chairman, Sir, we all know that sometime last year an unfortunate blunder was made on somebody's part when academic freedom amongst the students was attacked, when a prosecution for sedition in a University publication was brought against the editorial board of a certain student magazine. I find it difficult to assess even now the damage that the prosecution has done. It was fortunate indeed that a district judge - and I am proud to say that it was an Asian (he was born and bred in this country) - decided to throw the prosecution out of hand.

    The Attorney-General (Mr C. H. Butterfield) rose -

    The Chairman: Point of order?

    Mr Butterfield: Point of order, Sir. My point of order relates to Standing Order 15 (1) (g). It seems to me, Sir, that the speaker was going rather close in what he said to reflecting on a decision of a court of law.

    The Chairman: The Standing Order in question reads:

    "Every question shall conform to the following rules: -

    A question shall not reflect on the decision of a court of law .."

    There is no question of this nature before the House at all. The word "question" refers to questions to Ministers. Can you enlarge on your point of order, Mr Attorney-General?

Column: 1236



    Mr Butterfield: The question is not whether I wish to or not, but I think I should, Sir. My recollection of the Standing Order was not as clear as it might have been, and it is clear as you have already ruled, Sir, that my point was not well taken.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, that was perhaps what might have happened when the decision to prosecute the students was made.

    It is essential for an institution for higher learning that there should be absolute academic freedom. This includes the freedom to discuss any political subject and to adopt any political attitude, within the confines of that academic institution. Since the salutary effect of the dismissal of that prosecution, the authorities have been more tolerant and more liberal in their attitude to the students' political activities. But I wish today to bring to the notice of this House the fact that the authorities have not shown that same academic tolerance to its teaching staff. The Hon. the Chief Minister, Sir, knows personally of the case where a teacher in the University was about to be dismissed because he held views which were not palatable or not acceptable to his head of department and to the University.

    The Chief Minister rose -

    The Chairman: Point of order?

    The Chief Minister: Will the hon. Member permit a point of explanation? In fairness to him, I should say that I am conscious of the person to whom the Member for Tanjong Pagar has referred, and in fairness to the University authorities with whom I have discussed the matter, there was no question of his political views being taken into consideration but only the question of his health and his standard of work, and that ultimately he was, in fact, engaged.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: I am much obliged to the Chief Minister for his elaboration. Ultimately, after the personal intervention of the Chief Minister who knew the facts of the case, particularly from the point of view of the person who was to be victimised, he was
